snippet.textDisplay:
Class act all 3 are Master Musician.

Started to learn about them in my high school days with Moving Pictures and Signals album.

Mr. Peart, you don't know how much joy you have given us.

snippet.textDisplay: Been listening to rush for 20+ years, since I was like 11 years old. Never heard a 5 piece band make more full, complete or artistic music than this 3 piece band.
snippet.textOriginal: Been listening to rush for 20+ years, since I was like 11 years old. Never heard a 5 piece band make more full, complete or artistic music than this 3 piece band.

snippet.textDisplay:
I think Neil Peart is very unique in rock music history. Really the whole band is. The guys in Rush are very different than the guys in Kiss or Van Halen or ACDC Led Zeppelin or the Who. I don't think Neil Peart ever wanted to be a rock star. He was just a guy who really enjoyed playing drums and music. He was never comfortable with all the fame and attention he received. A lot of people thought he was very arrogant and conceited because he wouldn't sign autographs or interact with fans, but I think he was just a very quiet and shy and humble person. I don't think he ever thought or said "I am the greatest drummer ever". Lots of other people thought and said that about him, but he never thought or said that about himself. I don't think any drummer in history actively contributed to the success of his band more than Neil Peart. Bands like the Beatles and the Rolling Stones and U2 and Bon Jovi all would have been just as successful with any one of 10,000 different drummers. Rush would not have been nearly as successful with a typical rock drummer.

Neil Peart inspired thousands of people to play drums and made helped make millions of people happy with his music and lyrics. I am one of them. It's very sad that when he finally retires from drumming and recording and touring and just wants to spend time with his new family, he gets a terminal illness. I think the saddest part about his death is not that thousands of drummers and music fans have lost a hero, but that a little girl has lost her dad.

snippet.textDisplay:
Jesus. I feel like I lost a best friend. I learned how to play guitar by burning out my RUSH albums, playing them over and over again until they sounded so crappy I had to replace them. God bless you, Neil Peart (PRONOUNCED PEERT, not PERT). I love you man, and thank you for all the amazing music and insights into life that your lyrics gave me. I have grown up largely in the musical shadow of RUSH, and it makes up a huge portion of my world view. I hope your passing was painless, and that your loved ones grieve well. You will be remembered forever, Neil - You were, and are, the greatest drummer on Earth.
Rob Hale
snippet.textOriginal:
Jesus.  I feel like I lost a best friend.  I learned how to play guitar by burning out my RUSH albums, playing them over and over again until they sounded so crappy I had to replace them.  God bless you, Neil Peart (PRONOUNCED PEERT, not PERT).  I love you man, and thank you for all the amazing music and insights into life that your lyrics gave me.  I have grown up largely in the musical shadow of RUSH, and it makes up a huge portion of my world view.  I hope your passing was painless, and that your loved ones grieve well.  You will be remembered forever, Neil - You were, and are, the greatest drummer on Earth.
Rob Hale

snippet.textDisplay:
I am not a star struck kind of person--celebrities generally don't impress me--they are people after all. But Neil Peart's passing has struck a deep chord with me. I think it is because he was such an old soul; he was a shy, quiet, and private man; and he lead such a tragic life. The musical world has lost an icon, and the world has lost an amazing human being!
My heart goes out to his family and his bandmates.
snippet.textOriginal:
I am not a star struck kind of person--celebrities generally don't impress me--they are people after all.  But Neil Peart's passing has struck a deep chord with me.  I think it is because he was such an old soul; he was a shy, quiet, and private man; and he lead such a tragic life.  The musical world has lost an icon, and the world has lost an amazing human being!
My heart goes out to his family and his bandmates.

snippet.textDisplay: Rick, watching your video was just a reflection of exactly what I was feeling. I cried my eyes out and still can’t wrap my head around it. He was my hero and inspiration for playing the drums. I can’t tell you what an influence he has been on me as a musician. From the first time I heard Rush, I was hooked. Iconic doesn’t begin to describe him. The legacy that he leaves behind is the amazing gift of the Rush catalog and so much more. He was a very private guy and would not have wanted fans to grieve him prematurely. Shocked, crushed, saddened but most of all thankful and blessed to have experienced Rush live in concert so many times over the years. Godspeed Professor.
snippet.textOriginal: Rick, watching your video was just a reflection of exactly what I was feeling. I cried my eyes out and still can’t wrap my head around it. He was my hero and inspiration for playing the drums. I can’t tell you what an influence he has been on me as a musician. From the first time I heard Rush, I was hooked. Iconic doesn’t begin to describe him. The legacy that he leaves behind is the amazing gift of the Rush catalog and so much more. He was a very private guy and would not have wanted fans to grieve him prematurely. Shocked, crushed, saddened but most of all thankful and blessed to have experienced Rush live in concert so many times over the years. Godspeed Professor.

snippet.textDisplay: I'm a guitarist and first got into Rush because of Alex, about 1980, but Neil quickly became the first drummer I really took notice of.  It's parts were always perfect -- not just the execution, but the composition as well.  Sometimes it was the little things that got me most, like coming OUT of the drum fill section of Tom Sawyer when Neil kicks the energy level up.  He had incredible feel and a instinct for what a great drummer could add to music.  Hearing about his passing hit me like a ton of bricks.  I'd already largely accepted that we were unlikely to hear him play again.  But the idea that his talent is gone forever -- it's a lot to take in.
snippet.textOriginal: I'm a guitarist and first got into Rush because of Alex, about 1980, but Neil quickly became the first drummer I really took notice of.  It's parts were always perfect -- not just the execution, but the composition as well.  Sometimes it was the little things that got me most, like coming OUT of the drum fill section of Tom Sawyer when Neil kicks the energy level up.  He had incredible feel and a instinct for what a great drummer could add to music.  Hearing about his passing hit me like a ton of bricks.  I'd already largely accepted that we were unlikely to hear him play again.  But the idea that his talent is gone forever -- it's a lot to take in.

snippet.textDisplay: Rush is one of the first bands to make an impact on me in my teenage years, and one of my top 3 influences musically. I got to see them twice after Snakes and Arrows and once on the Time Machine Tour. Their shows were incredibly memorable and lit up all of my senses. I feel blessed to have been able to experience them when they were still at the top of their game. The world will be a little emptier without the Professor.

I feel blessed to have been able to experience them when they were still at the top of their game. The world will be a little emptier without the Professor.

snippet.textDisplay: I’m not a drummer. But I am proudly Canadian and have loved Rush since I was 8.  I live not far from where his daughter died.  I have always admired Neil Peart so much.  And Canada adored him. We have had 2 legendary Canadian musicians both die of the same brain cancer (RIP Gord Downie).  I thank you both for having the bravery and desire to record this tribute. It could not have been easy. Bless you both. Peace to Neil and to all his family.
snippet.textOriginal: I’m not a drummer. But I am proudly Canadian and have loved Rush since I was 8.  I live not far from where his daughter died.  I have always admired Neil Peart so much.  And Canada adored him. We have had 2 legendary Canadian musicians both die of the same brain cancer (RIP Gord Downie).  I thank you both for having the bravery and desire to record this tribute. It could not have been easy. Bless you both. Peace to Neil and to all his family.

snippet.textDisplay:
He completely changed the course of the band when he joined. They might have disappeared into obscurity if not for his drumming, and more importantly his imaginative and very literate lyrics.
They were a Bad Company cover band before Neil. He literally altered rock history.

snippet.textDisplay:
I Been listening to nothing but Rush CD since Sunday. For last two years after News years seems i start off the year listening to RUSH and Frank Marino.. I Don't know why.
. Rush Is and was the only band that every member got along always.. Never no DRAMA between them. Truly a Band of Brother's..Neil was in a class of his own The band was in a class of their own and untouchable.
Neil your Loved by all..and thank you for you made a difference to millions and made the world a better place. As one of the best trio of all Time in my book .Peace love and many blessing to peart family and to Alex and Geddy. .. You definitely will be missed by millions. .
RIP Neil From all of us in The Grand Canyon State.

snippet.textDisplay: To be honest. Rush did retire a couple years ago so on a good note...they had completed their musical journey and catalog. And they also got inducted into the RR HOF while Neil was still here. But there is some feeling so empty to have the idea of that trio now down to 2 and you know there could NEVER be a replacement.
snippet.textOriginal: To be honest. Rush did retire a couple years ago so on a good note...they had completed their musical journey and catalog. snippet.textDisplay:
This hurts more - and it shows.
Some are dying old, after a long life. Sad, but not unexpectable.
Some are dying way too young. You might blame them for having abused their health in some way. Very sad, but not too surprising.
And then are those, where you can assume, having taken most effort in getting around all their problems in a most responsible way,
- like Neil Peart - and still they have to go way too early. That is, why it feels totally unfair - and therefore it is so shocking .
I think we all feel, Neil Peart has earned a long, peaceful, relaxed, joyful eventide. So - why the f*ck NOT?
snippet.textOriginal:

snippet.textDisplay: Saw them in 79 and 80 Hammersmith Odeon. Met them backstage. Still have my signed Permanent waves programme. RIP Neil = Legend.

snippet.textDisplay: I am 57 and in my 70"s Australia bedroom ,  I fell in love with with Prog music and it was all about Genesis and Yes,and some obscure band band called RUSH?. In that decade my musical world and my life changed forever. Thank you Neil for being a class human and a thoughtful human and an intricate composer of drumming parts that captivated my teenage headphones. Oh ,,,,and of course there were some lyrics right?   'This just can't be understood" Best wishes for your family and know that I will never forget you and how you fed my life..RIP Neil Peart.
snippet.textOriginal: I am 57 and in my 70"s Australia bedroom ,  I fell in love with with Prog music and it was all about Genesis and Yes,and some obscure band band called RUSH?. snippet.textDisplay: I new Geddy from before Rush because my bass player was a friend. I met Alex once ...he was very, very shy. My band Tallis an all original Prog Rock band opened for Rush just weeks before their first LP came out. Rush started out as a Led Zep cover band until Geddy heard YES! lol  Yes they are as humble and unaffected as they were in '69.

snippet.textDisplay: Neil Peart, Rest in Peace... am truly saddened by your passing... been listening to Rush since 1977 or 78 when I was introduced by an old friend of mine... Have enjoyed them since and been fortunate enough to see them a few times... have also introduced them to other generations... from everything I've ever seen, or read, or heard, Neil Peart was far more than the sum of all his parts. Truly a great person.He will be missed.

snippet.textDisplay: Neal's playing introduced me to playing style and drum technique that I never knew was possible before. My next album with my current band will have a few nods to Rush and Niel. Thanks again Niel.

snippet.textDisplay: What a shock RIP Neil
snippet.textOriginal: What a shock RIP Neil

snippet.textDisplay: I have been a fan since I was about 8. My elder brother had some RUSH albums and I got interested right at the moment I heard them. Those strange rhythms, beautiful melodies, amazing drumsolo, fine guitar riffs, driving bass lines... Later I started playing bass myself, and RUSH was always one of the bands I loved the most. I've seen them live every time the came up to the The Netherlands. Neil contributed a lot in learning English when I started analysing the lyrics, and later his books. It is so sad, such a beautiful person! My condolances go to his familie, to Geddy and Alex and their families, to all their friends and of course to all the fans. He will stay in our hearts, and live on in the music. Rest in peace.
snippet.textOriginal: I have been a fan since I was about 8. My elder brother had some RUSH albums and I got interested right at the moment I heard them. snippet.textDisplay:
I don't know if it's because it was so sudden, or because he was so young (relatively).
I think we cry for our loss, I cried today, and thought about it, as sad as him leaving us to the great unknown is, I think I watched my life flash before my eyes today and that is what brought most of the tears.
Literally the sound track of most of my life.

snippet.textDisplay: Rest In Peace, Neil. One of our most beloved drummers and writers. He was one of the biggest supporters of keeping the spirit of Buddy Rich alive. Thank goodness we have all of Neil's recordings to keep us together. Let us give thanks that Neil lived amongst us. Condolences to all.
snippet.textOriginal: Rest In Peace, Neil. One of our most beloved drummers and writers. He was one of the biggest supporters of keeping the spirit of Buddy Rich alive. Thank goodness we have all of Neil's recordings to keep us together. Let us give thanks that Neil lived amongst us. Condolences to all.

snippet.textDisplay:
I was a dyed in the wool country music fan throughout elementary and part of Jr. High, then an amazing thing happened, I heard Tom Sawyer. I was instantly hooked and inspired.
I went and bought "Moving Pictures" and was amazed at the genius of Neil Peart's work and that goes for Geddy and Alez too.
I think all three of them are truly a National Treasure for Canada and America as well, Canada would do well to mark the release date of their first record as a National Holiday.
My condolences go out to Neil's family and I have a feeling Alex and Geddy fit in there with family.
I like to think he's once again with his wife and daughter, RIP Neil.

snippet.textDisplay: Yes I heard it on Facebook too I had to read it a three or 4 times just to make sure I wasn't imagining it.. blew me away.. is lyrics and drumming a part of my soul. I thought to myself this is what I've been looking for my whole life even know I was a teenager I knew this would last forever.. 59 and now I still listen to them at least once or twice a week when I get the chance.. have a good thing in my car

snippet.textDisplay: He was quite simply THE greatest drummer of all time. I doubt anyone will ever come close to what he accomplished. A kind, private soul. An amazing lyricist who’s words will echo now through time. I’m devastated but will remain forever grateful I lived in a time where I could bear witness to such stellar talent. “Suddenly you were gone, from all the lives you left your Mark upon...” Neil Peart. A legend for all time.
snippet.textOriginal: He was quite simply THE greatest drummer of all time. I doubt anyone will ever come close to what he accomplished. A kind, private soul. snippet.textDisplay: When I heard the news of Neil’s passing, I listened to Afterimage, Time Stand Still, and The Garden. It was during The Garden that I lost it and cried uncontrollably. I want that song played at my funeral...

snippet.textDisplay:
3:22 I felt that. Not only they were all amazing musicians, but they were also the nicest and most down-to-earth guys the rock industry had to offer. Especially Neil, that even after that excruciating family tragedy, found it in himself to make music, love and laugh again. Truly an amazing human being with a colossal heart, we'll miss him dearly.

Edit: corrected a typo

snippet.textDisplay: Love the emotional projection. Consolidates the bond between all of us under this tough news.
snippet.textOriginal: Love the emotional projection. Consolidates the bond between all of us under this tough news.

snippet.textDisplay: In an interview with Alex and Geddy, I recall Geddy mentioning that Neil had not only retired from Rush, but he had retired from drumming. I suspect Alex and Geddy knew the brain cancer diagnosis and treatment, and the Rush "family" preserved Neil's privacy for the four years following his diagnosis after their last 2015 tour ended. It was important that Neil spent time with his new family after losing his first family.
snippet.textOriginal: In an interview with Alex and Geddy, I recall Geddy mentioning that Neil had not only retired from Rush, but he had retired from drumming. I suspect Alex and Geddy knew the brain cancer diagnosis and treatment, and the Rush "family" preserved Neil's privacy for the four years following his diagnosis after their last 2015 tour ended. It was important that Neil spent time with his new family after losing his first family.

snippet.textDisplay: He taught me so much!! I learned about Samuel Taylor Coleridge listening to the lyrics of Xanadu at age 12. So crushed!! Your art will live forever Neil!! R.I.P.
snippet.textOriginal: He taught me so much!! I learned about Samuel Taylor Coleridge listening to the lyrics of Xanadu at age 12. So crushed!! Your art will live forever Neil!! R.I.P.

snippet.textDisplay:
It literally shocked me when my wife told me Neil was dead.

I had to take a moment. I had to apologize for getting emotional.
From the late 70s till...well forever, Rush as a band was, and I know this is cliche, the soundtrack of
my life. They where always there, and always would be there. Of course we are as Sunlion put it,
"Only immortal for a limited time". Neil, like Geddy and Alex have that odd location in my heart where,
even though I don't know them personally, there art was so intimate to my life that it always felt like
I could just invite them over for dinner, or to a bar or any personal moment because they'd literally
with there music, been in my life at those times anyway.

I was, and still am, inspired by the man. He rose up from the ashes (read Ghostrider) and made /more/
art when we, as fans, at least locally, felt Rush was done with Test For Echo.
Rest well sir, you've glued together the broken souls of people you never knew.

Rest well sir, you've glued together the broken souls of people you never knew.

snippet.textDisplay: Listening to Peart play kicked my ass into high drive. His drum parts were something complex but simple enough to expand your understanding as a drummer.
snippet.textOriginal: Listening to Peart play kicked my ass into high drive. His drum parts were something complex but simple enough to expand your understanding as a drummer.

snippet.textDisplay:
For those wondering if Neil was an Atheist and those going around trying to troll BS to people stating they're upset, crying and more, God forbid they say, God Bless Neil, there are a few or more jumping to every video. Do not listen. Let's listen to Neil;
in The Masked Rider: Cycling in West Africa, in which he wrote: "I'm a linear thinking agnostic, but not an atheist, folks." Neil would most likely not answer Religious question for he might think it's no one's business, he was a private man. Seems he had to comment in his book to dispel rumors when he was alive. We are just past 24 hours in hearing he passed and he still can't live down the silly rumors, yet he answered everyone. So listen to him. I'm sure (jmho) he'd want to see his daughter and late wife again. So why take a chance... ??? By no means was he stupid!
So, please anyone commenting rudely or just asking... No one knows but Neil and God... Now's really not the time for some of us are deeply affected by this. So please give Neil some respect and the fans, first and foremost his family friends and brothers Geddy and Alex. Having a hard time with this myself, but I say, Godspeed 'Professor' and may you be with your loved ones in Heaven or may they have been waiting for you. Be at Peace now Warrior
Many Blessings to everyone.
snippet.textOriginal:
For those wondering if Neil was an Atheist and those going around trying to troll BS to people stating they're upset, crying and more, God forbid they say, God Bless Neil, there are a few or more jumping to every video. Do not listen. Let's listen to Neil;
   in The Masked Rider: Cycling in West Africa, in which he wrote: "I'm a linear thinking agnostic, but not an atheist, folks." Neil would most likely not answer Religious question for he might think it's no one's business, he was a private man. Seems he had to comment in his book to dispel rumors when he was alive. We are just past 24 hours in hearing he passed and he still can't live down the silly rumors, yet he answered everyone. So listen to him. I'm sure (jmho) he'd want to see his daughter and late wife again. So why take a chance... ??? By no means was he stupid!
   So, please anyone commenting rudely or just asking... No one knows but Neil and God... Now's really not the time for some of us are deeply affected by this. So please give Neil some respect and the fans, first and foremost his family friends and brothers Geddy and Alex. Having a hard time with this myself, but I say, Godspeed 'Professor' and may you be with your loved ones in Heaven or may they have been waiting for you. Be at Peace now Warrior 
    Many Blessings to everyone.

snippet.textDisplay:
I’m learning of his death from this video.

Mr. Peart’s life was one marked with tragic deaths. For him, the cycle has finally ended. I hope that his soul is finally at peace.

A few of my childhood buddies were drummers who idolized him, I’m certain that they’re also saddened by his passing.

(John Rutsey was the drummer on Rush’s first album, which includes “Working Man”.)
snippet.textOriginal:

snippet.textDisplay: Thank you Rick and Jack. I’ve been a Rush fan since 1982 here in Australia where, with my small group of friends considered ourselves the only Rush fans in this city. All the same, I feel a connection with all other Rush fans around the world, the respect felt for Neil is shared by all that have been touched by his music, lyrics, philosophies and humanity. Neil’s drumming is a massive part of the soundtrack to my youth and I’m one of the thousands to feel appreciative of The Professor for sharing his talents.
snippet.textOriginal: Thank you Rick and Jack. I’ve been a Rush fan since 1982 here in Australia where, with my small group of friends considered ourselves the only Rush fans in this city. All the same, I feel a connection with all other Rush fans around the world, the respect felt for Neil is shared by all that have been touched by his music, lyrics, philosophies and humanity. Neil’s drumming is a massive part of the soundtrack to my youth and I’m one of the thousands to feel appreciative of The Professor for sharing his talents.

snippet.textDisplay: This is truly one of the saddest days in music history. Rush has been one of my favorite bands of all time. I would like to send my condolences to Neil"s family and to Gady and Alex . The one thing that saddens me the most is that I never got to see them live in concert. Neil gave so much to us in the way of the music. Neil was and always will be the greatest drummer that ever sat behind a set of drums. I am a fellow Canadian(Kingston, Ontario). God bless you Neil and thank you so very much for everything that you gave us. R.I.P

snippet.textDisplay: Thank you for doing this tribute. It's hard to know what to say. I've been listening to Rush since my mid-teens (mid-80s) and I always focused on Neil's playing and the thoughtfulness and intellect of his lyrics. RIP Neil. God bless!
snippet.textOriginal: Thank you for doing this tribute. It's hard to know what to say. I've been listening to Rush since my mid-teens (mid-80s) and I always focused on Neil's playing and the thoughtfulness and intellect of his lyrics. RIP Neil. God bless!

snippet.textDisplay:
Rick - You and Jack spoke it almost perfect. There are not enough superlatives to describe what a person Neil Peart was. Honestly, I was waiting to see your video about this - and you nailed it. I am at a loss myself. Neil was someone I would probably never meet, but would have a thousand questions for if I did. As a kid in school, and now, I am not one to jump on 'fanwagons' and thought Rush was 'uncool'. I was so wrong. I started marching drum corps at 14 and playing drums. I think in 1986 we had two guys join that were big Rush fans. 'Moving Pictures' and 'Exit Stage Left' were played constantly on the boombox.
We - the drumline - learned those songs forwards and backwards - and played them on the line. I pushed for a year for us to play 'Witch Hunt" in our program. When I finally got a drumset, I had known how to play most of 'Moving Pictures' without having touched a drumset.
When I was 20, I had two guys approach me about getting into a band. I told them I would think about it. After a few beers, I called the local radio station (105.7 WAPL) an asked them to play 'Limelight'. After they did, I called them back and told them they just gave one drummer the kick in the he needed to be a drummer.

Thank you Rick
snippet.textOriginal:
Rick - You and Jack spoke it almost perfect. There are not enough superlatives to describe what a person Neil Peart was. Honestly, I was waiting to see your video about this - and you nailed it. I am at a loss myself. Neil was someone I would probably never meet, but would have a thousand questions for if I did. As a kid in school, and now, I am not one to jump on 'fanwagons' and thought Rush was 'uncool'. I was so wrong. I started marching drum corps at 14 and playing drums. I think in 1986 we had two guys join that were big Rush fans. 'Moving Pictures' and 'Exit Stage Left' were played constantly on the boombox.
We - the drumline - learned those songs forwards and backwards - and played them on the line. I pushed for a year for us to play 'Witch Hunt" in our program. When I finally got a drumset, I had known how to play most of 'Moving Pictures' without having touched a drumset. 
When I was 20, I had two guys approach me about getting into a band. I told them I would think about it. After a few beers, I called the local radio station (105.7 WAPL) an asked them to play 'Limelight'. After they did, I called them back  and told them they just gave one drummer the kick in the he needed to be a drummer.

Thank you Rick

snippet.textDisplay: I am 54.  I love RUSH!!   My favorite band PERIOD.   RUSH I believe was not going to perform again.  But I know they, all 3 are still here.  That was good enough.  And then this news.  And now its just 2.  It’s numbing.   One song lyric I immediately remember from the Power Windows Album...’You can do a lot in a lifetime, if you don’t burn out to fast.....you can make the most of the distances ....first you need endurance....first you got last..... ☹️🥁
snippet.textOriginal: I am 54.  I love RUSH!!   My favorite band PERIOD.   RUSH I believe was not going to perform again.  But I know they, all 3 are still here.  That was good enough.
